questions.question: When preparing a 0.1M standard solution, which factor is MOST critical for achieving accurate concentration?

answers.a: Precise weighing of the primary standard

explanations.a: Accurate weighing is fundamental for preparing standard solutions of precise molarity.
explanations.b: Color has no effect on solution concentration.
explanations.c: While dissolution is important, speed doesn't affect final concentration.
explanations.d: Storage temperature matters for stability but not initial preparation accuracy.

questions.question: Which characteristic is NOT required for a chemical to be suitable as a primary standard?

explanations.a: High MW is actually desirable (though not absolutely required) for better weighing accuracy.
explanations.b: Stability is essential for reliable standards.
explanations.c: Fluorescence has no relevance to standard qualification.
explanations.d: High purity is absolutely necessary for primary standards.

questions.question: What is the purpose of performing multiple standardizations of a reagent solution?

answers.a: To improve the precision of the concentration determination
answers.b: To change the solution's chemical properties
answers.c: To make the solution more concentrated
answers.d: To reduce the volume of solution needed

explanations.a: Replicate standardizations reduce random errors and improve precision.
explanations.d: Volume requirements aren't changed by repeated standardization.

questions.question: Why should standard solutions be stored in tightly sealed containers?

answers.a: To prevent contamination and concentration changes
answers.b: To make them easier to identify
answers.c: To protect them from light only

explanations.a: Sealing prevents evaporation (concentration changes) and contamination.
explanations.b: Identification is done by labeling, not sealing.
explanations.c: While light protection is important for some standards, it's not the main reason for sealing.
explanations.d: Gas exchange would alter the solution composition.

questions.question: A 0.1N solution of HCl was standardized against sodium carbonate. The titration required 25.4 mL of HCl to reach the endpoint with 0.134g Na₂CO₃. What is the exact normality of the HCl? (MW Na₂CO₃ = 106 g/mol)

explanations.a: Correct calculation: meq Na₂CO₃ = 0.134g/(106 g/mol ÷ 2) = 0.002528 meq; N HCl = meq/volume = 0.002528/0.0254 L = 0.0994 N
explanations.b: This would be the approximate value without considering exact measurements.
explanations.c: This might result from miscalculating the equivalent weight.
explanations.d: This would represent a significant calculation error.

questions.question: Which of these errors would MOST significantly affect standardization results?

answers.a: Not correcting for the indicator blank
answers.d: Using a plastic beaker for mixing

explanations.a: Indicator blank corrections are crucial for precise standardization.
explanations.b: Small temperature variations have minimal effect if solutions are equilibrated.
explanations.c: Daylight typically doesn't affect most standardizations.
explanations.d: Plastic beakers are acceptable for many standardizations.
